Ted Carter
Researcher. Project Manager. Liberal. Agnostic. White. Male. Heterosexual. Cisgender. Nerd. Geek. Father. Husband. American?
Feb 6

Back to the Rulebook, Americans.

Look, Americans, it’s time to get over ourselves.

No more liberals “trolling” Trump supporters or Trump supporters “shutting down” liberals. No more unjustified righteous indignation. No more scapegoating. No more self-perpetuating bubbles of agreement where no progress is made. No more hating people based on labels we arbitrarily assign to them.

No. More.

I, like many, have been disgusted by what “the other side” has been producing in terms of half-truths and slanted perspectives. But as time goes on and people get more angry and more frustrated, it become easier to see that both “sides” are becoming equally guilty of these errors.

And let me clarify that I am talking about people outside of the government itself at this point. I am talking about “the common man.” I don’t want to step into the discussion of what The White House or POTUS or The Supreme Court are doing in this article, but instead focus on the citizens. I am also not talking about media organizations directly, because with such organizations there is a question of motive. So let us assume that we are talking about people who legitimately want to know the “truth” and promote what they believe to be right.

We need to be critical consumers and producers of information. In the end, this all comes back down to logical arguments. Unfortunately, Americans are proving to be wholly incompetent when it comes to having such arguments.

So let’s review some basic do’s and don’ts of logical argument. I am relying on Anthony Weston’s “A Rulebook for Arguments” for this list, using the headings he uses in his chapters. If you haven’t read the book, I highly recommend it.

DO’s:

  1. Identify premises and conclusions.
  2. Develop your ideas in a natural order.
  3. Start from reliable premises.
  4. Be concrete and concise.
  5. Build on substance, not overtone.
  6. Use consistent terms.
  7. Use more than one example.
  8. Use representative examples.
  9. Background rates may be crucial.
  10. Statistics need a critical eye.
  11. Consider counterexamples.
  12. Analogies require relevantly similar examples.
  13. Cite your sources.
  14. Seek informed sources.
  15. Seek impartial sources.
  16. Cross-check sources.
  17. Use the web with care.
  18. Causal arguments start with correlation.
  19. Correlations may have alternative explanations.
  20. Work toward the most likely explanation.
  21. Expect complexity.

Weston goes on to describe the basic forms of argument, but we won’t go into that here.

What about the DON’Ts? We call those “logical fallacies.” This is where the real fun begins.

DON’Ts:

  1. Ad Hominem: Attack the person making the argument rather than the argument itself.
  2. Ad Ignoratiam: Argue that something is true simply because it has not been proven to be false.
  3. Ad misericordiam: Appeal to pity.
  4. Ad populum: Argue that something is right because “everyone” is doing it or “everyone” believes it.
  5. Affirm the consequent: Argue as follows: If p, then q. q, therefore p. Weston’s example: “When the roads are icy, the mail is late. The mail is late. Therefore, the roads are icy.”
  6. Beg the question: Include your conclusion in one of your argument’s premises. Weston’s example: “The Bible is true, because God wrote it. The Bible says that God exists. Therefore, God exists.”
  7. Use a complex question: Ask a question in such a way that requires the respondent to accept a claim you wish to promote. One of Weston’s examples: “Are you still as self-centered as you used to be?”
  8. Deny the antecedent: Argue as follows: If p, then q. Not p, therefore Not q. Weston’s example: “When the roads are icy, the mail is late. The roads are not icy. Therefore, the mail is not late.”
  9. Equivocate: Switch the meaning of one or more of your terms in the middle of an argument.
  10. Present a false dilemma: Reduce your options to two diametrically opposed choices when there are others. Weston’s example: “America: Love it or Leave it.”
  11. Load your language: Deliberately use language that supports one side of the argument.
  12. Overgeneralize: Draw conclusions from too few examples.
  13. Overlook alternatives: Fail to acknowledge other possible explanations when asserting a particular conclusion.
  14. Use persuasive definitions: Define terms in a way that favors one side of an argument.
  15. Poison the well: Use loaded language to disfavor an argument before presenting it. Weston’s example: “No sensitive person thinks that…”
  16. Post hoc, ergo propter hoc: Assert that because something came after something else, it was caused by it.
  17. Use red herrings: Introducing another topic to distract attention away from the original argument.
  18. Use straw man: Exaggerate or distort the opposing view so as to make it sound ridiculous and easy to refute.

Regardless of your political slant, you can no doubt find examples of how “the other side” has used any of the 18 fallacies above to try and win an argument. But I want you to work a little harder and see how people whose views align with your own have also used these fallacies. Once you can do that, you are one step closer to being able to recognize when you do it in your own arguments.

Thus endeth today’s lesson.
